title: To study and compare various software process models

process_models.name: Waterfall Model
process_models.objective: (first introduced)Sequential Phases of software development;
process_models.pros: simple to adapt; best suitable for small projects / very clear requirements; easier to test and analyze
process_models.cons: Only matches precise needs; requirements unclear because end-user/client can't see the working software (blurry requirements); high cost for implementing creative work after adapted; hard to estimate/predict cost, deadline, limitation; can't apply to maintenance project

process_models.name: Royce's final model**
process_models.objective: improvised waterfall model; feedback->design->requirement
process_models.pros: overlapping of stage is possible according to feedback from client

process_models.name: The Sashimi Model
process_models.objective: waterfall model with overlapping phases; most appropriate for medium-sized projects
process_models.pros: implementation issue might be discovered during design and implementation
process_models.cons: rework needed if requirement changes after design or coding

process_models.name: Plan Driven Development
process_models.objective: project success directly depends on how the plan is followed and requirement stability;
process_models.pros: less cost to requirement changes before design
process_models.cons: costly to adapt to changes after design; highly dependent on requirement stability

process_models.name: Prototyping
process_models.objective: initial prototype developed to validate requirements, identify problems and solution for the problems
process_models.pros: possible to determine clear idea about functional process of software/product; low failure risk in software functionality
process_models.cons: over threshold involvement of client can affect development process; too many changes(patches) affect system flow(i.e. might become hard to debug after too many patches)

process_models.name: Incremental Development
process_models.objective: evolving software from initial implementation to operational software with several versions of user feedback
process_models.pros: user can validate system with respect to requirements delivery at early stages
process_models.cons: later stages might become costlier in adapting changes as previous/existing system modules becomes degraded; due addition of new features, system architecture might face issue which may not exist in earlier stages

process_models.name: Spiral
process_models.objective: cyclical model; producing prototype in each cycle for testing and risk analysis until software is operational (as per requirements/desire)
process_models.pros: risk factors are reduced; suitable for large/complex projects; additional feature can be introduced
process_models.cons: costly model for development; final operational may starve as cycle may continue; project can be compromised if failed to evaluate risk analysis properly

process_models.name: Agile development
process_models.objective: fast catching up and flexible; targets tech industry, people and collaboration within; focuses on adapting changes and fast turnaround
process_models.pros: suitable for creative projects; easy to adapt creative ideas in existing framework/design; transparency maintains
process_models.cons: only focus on software work impact on documentation efficiency; path can be diverged as outcome seem unclear

process_models.name: Rapid application development (RAD)
process_models.objective: primary focus on providing quick results; a better development process with support of other development approaches
process_models.pros: effortless development process; quickly reviewable; ensures client inputs and feedback
process_models.cons: depends on overall team performance; requires person with highly adequate knowledge and skills; not suitable for small budget project

process_models.name: Dynamic Software Development Method (DSDM)
process_models.objective: derived from RAD; iterative + incremental; focuses on end-user/client involvement; primary focus on system development in deadline and allocated budget
process_models.pros: quick delivery of module(functionality); easy access to end user; determine project outcome earlier
process_models.cons: expensive implementation; not possible to adapt by small organization;

process_models.name: Continuous integration
process_models.objective: developers work as community and integrate/merge code in shared repository; build/merged changes are tested by automated software
process_models.pros: increase workflow process and saves time and effort(code break); bugs and defects can be detected earlier; reduces manual testing effort
process_models.cons: some typo mistake can be reveal to end user if it is deployed without manual verification

process_models.name: Continuous Deployment
process_models.objective: Continuous integration with automated deployment if codebase passes all test cases
process_models.pros: No need of manual deployment; bugs and defects can be detected earlier; quick feedback of system for business
process_models.cons: some typo mistake reveal to end user as soon as it is deployed

process_models.name: Extreme Programming (XP)
process_models.objective: accentuate teamwork (pair programming); responsive to changing requirements (continuous integration); frequent releases in short development cycles; code refactor, Planning; regular(daily) communication
process_models.pros: improve productivity; new requirements can be easily adopted; focuses on user feedback and involvement
process_models.cons: efficiency depends on involved people; future possibilities and outcome are unknown; requires regular communication/meeting raises cost

process_models.name: Scrum
process_models.objective: incremental+agile; focuses on short or quick deadline delivery of product;
process_models.pros: rapid feedback and quick response to changes; good productivity with adapting changes of requirements and feature; with every iterative feedback/meet/testing non-desire feature/bugs can be fixed easily
process_models.cons: as regular changes adapted and integrated project might not be well documented; require more experience of project handling; time frames might extended frequently to adapt changes

process_models.name: Iterative Development
process_models.objective: building small modules of all featured project; build project quickly for user feedback
process_models.pros: flexibility for changes; potential bugs/issues can be fixed at earlier stages; progress can be easily tracked
process_models.cons: might require more amount of resource; hard to determine deadline; require trained and skilled person for risk analysis

process_models.name: Feature Driven Development
process_models.objective: focused on serving large number of teams; suitable for large project
process_models.pros: successive progress in large projects; supports continuous update in project; end result always better then initial ones
process_models.cons: not suitable for small projects/single person; documentation barely maintained; doesn't guarantee deadline; much more dependable on leading developer

process_models.name: Reuse-oriented Software Engineering
process_models.objective: utilizing existing codebase similar to requirement;
process_models.pros: system delivery can be quicker;
process_models.cons: limited scopes; dependency issue may rise

process_models.name: Critical Chain / Path
process_models.objective: focuses to solve resource issues and design for teams of people with flexible skills; determine core element and deadline on its basis
process_models.pros: easy to collaborate; tracking and managing resources and developer is easier
process_models.cons: each stage plan may extend timeline hence might not suite to small projects

process_models.name: Projects integrating Sustainable Methods (PRiSM)
process_models.objective: focuses to account environmental factors; developed by GPM Global; used at large-scale construction(real-estate) projects
process_models.pros: shows client about seriousness of developer related to environmental factors
process_models.cons: can't work in isolation

process_models.name: Projects IN Controlled Environments (PRINCE2)
process_models.objective: de facto standard(convention) used by the UK government since 1996; process oriented; each stage with it's own plan;
process_models.pros: heavily documented; suitable for corporate entities
process_models.cons: it'll take amount of time to adapt changes (due to heavily documented)

process_models.name: Lean Development (LD)
process_models.objective: empowering team to produce great results with delivering ton of value while producing little project waste*;
process_models.pros: low cost budget; good for short deadline and resource; team is motivated to produce perfect feature
process_models.cons: depends on decision making (how quickly good decision are made); documentation needs to be precise and understandable

process_models.name: Rational Unified Process (RUP)
process_models.objective: Invented by Rational, a division of IBM; iterative waterfall (because it inherits best part of waterfall); 4 phases per project; 9 disciplines per phase[waterfall strategy to moving to next phase]
process_models.pros: best of waterflow with iterative approach
process_models.cons: too heavily relies on user feedback

process_models.name: Event Chain Methodology
process_models.objective: relationship between event and task and how they affect each other; focuses on planning for potential risks; handles impact of external events on project;
process_models.pros: allows to examine relationship between tasks and external pressures
process_models.cons: sometimes beneficial external events might be considered as threat by project manager

process_models.name: Kanban
process_models.objective: inherited from lean development; steady stream of product delivery; continuous workflow
process_models.pros: easy to track time; concentrates on most important feature; increases speed of development process; constant system improvements
process_models.cons: major variation in user requirements; length projects effectively don't get much benefits

process_models.name: Chaos model
process_models.objective: attempt towards fixing deadline management issues while fixing bugs and odds of system; problems are divided into levels; upper level -> users' need & bottom level -> define technical resource
process_models.pros: flexible & iterative ;
process_models.cons: high complexity to use and implement

process_models.name: B-model
process_models.objective: Extension to waterfall model; maintenance cycle added to water fall model;
process_models.pros: ensures constant improvements of system in development stages

process_models.name: V-model (vee model)
process_models.objective: developed by NASA; molded waterfall model in V shape; allows evolution of user requirements
process_models.pros: can utilize for large projects; quality assurance; the requirements & design are verifiable in a SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic and Timebound) manner; symmetric across two legs
process_models.cons: user friendly is non verifiable; limited scope to backed technologies and system

process_models.name: vee+ model
process_models.objective: variation of V-model; adds user involvement; adds user involvement, risks to z-axis of v-model
process_models.pros: can identify odds during integration phase; odds are resolved as errors/accepted as design feature
process_models.cons: suitable for system with backend and frontend (no business logic)

process_models.name: vee++ model
process_models.objective: adds intersecting processes to vee+ model; a decomposition analysis and resolution process is added
process_models.pros: utilization scope is not limited and hence suitable for all kind of system

process_models.name: Wheel-and-spoke Model
process_models.objective: based on spiral model; initially small teams; wheel represent development cycle; best suitable for multiple projects with identical architecture/feature
process_models.pros: negligible initial risk; scalable from small team and task to larger team depending on requirements; core code remains same hence code logic and quality will rise
process_models.cons: best suitable for only backed and frontend

process_models.name: Joint Application Development (JAD)
process_models.objective: collaborative development with customer/involving in design & development phases through workshops(JAD sessions)
process_models.pros: feasible for any system development; speed up development and delivery; improves quality of final system
process_models.cons: not cost effective (due to JAD sessions); lack of deadline; time commitment needs may not meet if multiple workshops relative to project size

process_models.name: Six Sigma
process_models.objective: management framework designed to be driven by data; developed my Motorola
process_models.pros: ensures product is 99.99966% error free; suggests improvements before defects even appear
process_models.cons: extremely rigid; limits creativity of developer

process_models.name: Test Driven Development (TDD)
process_models.objective: all iteration defined by a new test; expects new test fail so that new features implemented and fixed so that it works with old features
process_models.pros: improved stability of system; system is well tested and documented
process_models.cons: it takes more effort and time while writing test; require code refactor continuously; only few member of team uses TDD

process_models.name: Acceptance Test Driven Development (ATDD)
process_models.objective: involves members from different point of view in team to collaborate and write acceptance test; acceptance test act as form of requirements (customer -> what to solve? | Developer -> how to solve | testing -> what about..)
process_models.pros: provides interfaces specific to functional testing (without testing through actual UI)
process_models.cons: rely on some specific tools

process_models.name: Behaviour Driven Development (BDD)
process_models.objective: extension to TDD and ATDD with specification by example;
process_models.pros: also suitable and more precise at organizational level; target BDD tool (i.e. FitNesse) support generating technical and end-user document automatically; low cost and risk; eay to undo

process_models.name: Capability Maturity Model (CMM)
process_models.objective: developed by Software Engineering Institute (SEI), R&D center sponsored by the U.S. Dept. of Defense (DoD); similar to ISO 9001; framework establishment for continuous process improvement;
process_models.pros: five-level evolutionary organized and systematic path; optimize development, acquire, and maintain large-scale software-reliant systems
process_models.cons: costly process; not suitable for small organization; require leader with adequate field knowledge

process_models.name: Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI)
process_models.objective: meet challenges to trending global business; focused on improving usability of maturity models by integrating various different models into single framework
process_models.pros: trending process model to satisfy new technology/functionality; Appraisals of organizations using a CMMI model
process_models.cons: high cost (In March 2018 CMMI 2.0 introduced at minimum price of US$150.00)

process_models.name: Big-Bang Model
process_models.objective: no predefined process is followed; it only requires some planning and need not to follow formal development;
process_models.pros: simple; low budget; suitable for small team and project; suitable for academic project, students or new comers
process_models.cons: risk is very high; not suitable for long and complex project; the output developed prototype/product does not guarantee initial requirements to be met

process_models.name: Code and Fix Model
process_models.objective: it adds testing to big bang model; testing team/developer test the prototype and sends for fixes until it meets the requirement
process_models.pros: no burden of project planning; suitable for small project;
process_models.cons: Quality assessment is difficult; timeframe for release are not clear; hard to adopt requirement changes

process_models.name: Enterprise Unified Process (EUP)
process_models.objective: extended variant of UP(Unified Process) to fulfill lack of production and retirement of software system; embedded to life cycle of organization itself
process_models.pros: growing model(growing to Disciplined agile delivery (DAD)); higher quality; high adaptability; seen as end-user point of view

process_models.name: Disciplined agile delivery (DAD) - process decision framework
process_models.objective: incremental and iterative delivery of product; grown from Enterprise Unified Process (EUP); developed after 2013 with adopting best from many development process like agile/scrum/lean/etc.;
process_models.pros: 2nd generation framework; end-to-end method for agile delivery; hybrid agile; high scalability; goal driven; enterprise level; provides more affilated approach to agile software development; fills the gaps ignored by scrum; capable at enterprise level scale
references: Scott Ambler developed the disciplined agile development process during his time as chief methodologist for IT at IBM Rational (Summer 2006 to Summer 2012)
